If you feel, for safety reasons, a voter could opt out of public disclosure in the voter file
All classifications of users of the voter file would be self-described - the SotS office isnâ€™t and shouldnâ€™t determine who is a journalist or an academic
(The last 2 tweets, and going forward, are from questions from the GAE committee)
There are currently no restrictions at all on commercial use of the voter file
Although information is already out there, we shouldnâ€™t make it easier. The voter file has more than 2 million people and they deserve to have their data protected
Connecticut voters deserve to know that registering to vote will not, under any circumstances, open them up to identity fraud, voter suppression, or harassment
The days of our voter file being a potential tool of big data, voter suppression, and identity thieves are over
All the current users of the voter file to facilitate the democratic process, including the press and researchers, will be unaffected by this provision

Finally, the purpose of the voter file is to facilitate the democratic process. This proposal, like more than 1/3 of states, would restrict the voter file to political committees, candidates, journalists and the media, academic researchers, and for governmental functions

This bill would prevent the voter file from being used for harassment, stalking, and abuse, by allowing people to opt-out of public voter file disclosure if they believe it would be necessary for their own or their familyâ€™s safety
We would prohibit the use of the voter file for harassment, voter suppression or intimidation, personal use, or rebroadcasting online
We would prohibit the commercial use of the voter file, like 47 other states, because our voter file was meant to register voters, not to be a marketing list
About half the states have restrictions that prevent the full birth date from being publicly disseminated in the voter file

According to Frank Abagnale, former identity thief and subject of the film â€œCatch Me if You Can,â€ â€œIf you happen to tell me where you were born, your date of birth â€¦ then I'm 98 percent of the way to stealing your identity.â€ https://t.co/wwJaIjHNuS

Academics have called the birthdate the most dangerous bit of personal information that can fall into the wrong hands and demonstrated that a partial social security number can be estimated from a birthdate and a home state
Most importantly, if this proposal were to pass, we would stop giving out the month and day of birth in the publically available voter file, while leaving the year of birth intact

With that in mind, we looked at what other states are doing to protect their votersâ€™ personal information, and adapted what we thought would fit within our frame work of Freedom of Information and our culture of transparency, and discarded what wouldnâ€™t

I believe the voters are right. It is long past time to stop giving out so much personal information of Connecticut voters and allowing the voter file to contribute to this large, and growing, problem
There is always a balance between making public as much information as possible and protecting the personal information of Connecticutâ€™s voters
I have always been, and continue to be, deeply committed to protecting the publicâ€™s access to information

When Connecticut residents register to vote, they should only be concerned about which candidates to choose, they shouldnâ€™t have to worry that their personal information will be compromised, or their personal safety threatened
The voter file is meant to be a registry of voters. Full Stop.

I am also concerned that the ease by which the voter file is available makes it too easy for potential stalkers, harassers, and abusers to find the addresses and person information of their potential targets
There is hardly a single Connecticut resident that hasnâ€™t been touched by data breaches and the threat of identity theft

Voters are horrified to find out how much information is in the voter file that our office gives out in the voter file, and Every Equifax, every Target, every Home Depot, and every Anthem makes it worse

Last summer, in an attempt to justify President Trumpâ€™s claim that he lost the popular vote by 3 million votes because of millions of fraudulent votes, the â€œvoter fraudâ€ commission requested voter files, including info that is not normally public, like Social Security #s
In 2014, a former New Hampshire state legislator with a decidedly checkered history bought the Connecticut voter file and put it online on his ConnVoters website for the world to see
No issue has generated more calls or emails to my office, often emotional or even angry in tone, than the issue of what information is given out in the voter file
